title: Find Out How Much Traffic a Website Gets: 3 Ways Compared
description: Three most well-known ways to estimate website's traffic compared. Plus some advice on estimating website traffic with no tools at all.
content: Joshua Hardwick Head of Content @ Ahrefs (or, in plain English, I'm the guy responsible for ensuring that every blog post we publish is EPIC). Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents Do you want to see how much traffic a website gets? There are a few different ways to do this.Before I get to those, though, here‚Äôs an important point:If you own the website, there‚Äôs no need to estimate. You can install Google Analytics (for free) and see close to exact traffic numbers.Ahrefs‚Äô blog growth, via Google AnalyticsSidenote. Server log file analysis can provide even more data about your traffic, as explained in this article.But as you‚Äôre reading this article, I‚Äôll hazard a guess that you don‚Äôt own the website in question, right?You‚Äôre probably trying to guess how much traffic your competitor gets, and it‚Äôs unlikely that they‚Äôll share their Google Analytics with you.In this post, I‚Äôll run through three ways to get traffic estimates for any website.Method 1. Use a traffic estimation toolThere are two types of traffic estimation tools:Tools that estimate total traffic: Visitors to your website can come from all kinds of places: search engines; forums; social media; etc. These tools estimate the total amount of traffic from all sources.Tools that estimate only organic traffic: Most websites get a good chunk of their traffic from search engines like Google; this is called ‚Äúorganic traffic.‚Äù Estimates from these tools don‚Äôt take into account traffic from any other sources (e.g., social media) besides organic traffic.Let‚Äôs explore each of these in more detail.1. Find out how much traffic a website gets in totalHere at Ahrefs, we tried all the leading total traffic estimation tools and did a few small internal experiments to find out which was most accurate, and SimilarWeb won.SimilarWeb shows a bunch of traffic-related stats, including:Total visits;Pages per visit;Average visit duration;Bounce rateSidenote. Learn more about how Similarweb defines and calculates these metrics here, here, here and here.Here are the traffic estimates for ahrefs.com as of July 2018:Strangely, it doesn‚Äôt provide pageview estimates. But these can be reverse engineered by multiplying total visits by pages per visit (for us, this would be 5.63M * 7.5 = 42.23M pageviews).Free users can also view monthly traffic estimations for up to six months on an interactive graph.Paying subscribers can see this data for up to two years.All traffic estimates include both mobile and desktop traffic, and you can segment by device category if you‚Äôre a paying subscriber.Scroll down, and the report shows some more useful traffic-related stats such as traffic by countries (desktop only)‚Ä¶Sidenote. Free users can only see stats for the top 5 countries that drive the highest percentage of traffic.‚Ä¶ traffic sources (direct, referrals, search, etc)‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ top referring sites (this is useful when building links or looking for guest post opportunities that will bring referral traffic!)‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ and top 5 organic keywords‚Ä¶Where does the data come from?To understand the reliability of this data, it‚Äôs vital that we know where it comes from.Here‚Äôs what SimilarWeb has to say on the matter:Our data comes from 4 main sources:A panel of monitored devices, currently the largest in the industry;Local internet service providers (ISPs) located in many different countries;Our web crawlers that scan every public website to create a highly accurate map of the digital world;Hundreds of thousands of direct measurement sources from websites and apps that are connected to us directly.‚ÄùTranslation: SimilarWeb get their data from a variety of sources which collect anonymized information about users‚Äô online activity.They don‚Äôt say how big their coverage is, but they don‚Äôt get information from everyone in the world. So their data is derived from a relatively small sample of the ‚Äúonline population.‚ÄùIs the data accurate?Let‚Äôs test it. Here‚Äôs what we did:Took a sample of 116 websites from Flippa;Pulled total unique visitors and pageviews from Similarweb for all 116 sites;Compared them.Sidenote. We only used websites from Flippa that were at least one year old and had verified traffic.Here‚Äôs what we found:SimilarWeb overestimated total unique visitors for 91.67% of the websites.SimilarWeb overestimated total unique visitors by 308.81% on average;SimilarWeb overestimated total pageviews for 70.83% of the websites;SimilarWeb overestimated total pageviews by 210.58% on average.To summarise, SimilarWeb tends to drastically overestimate actual unique visitors and pageviews, according to our testing. But it doesn‚Äôt always overestimate things; it underestimates unique visitors roughly 1/12th of the time, and pageviews between ‚Öì and ¬º of the time.But here‚Äôs a critical point:SimilarWeb only showed estimates for roughly ‚Öï of the sites we tested. For the other ‚Öò, here‚Äôs what we saw:No data. Nada.If you‚Äôre wondering why this happened, it‚Äôs probably due to the size of the sites we tested. All of them were relatively small sites from Flippa.You‚Äôll remember that SimilarWeb calculates their estimates based on data from a small subset of the entire online population. So if they don‚Äôt show traffic estimates for a particular site, it‚Äôs because not enough people in the subset from which they derive their data have visited the website in question.That‚Äôs why SimilarWeb tends to have less or no data on smaller sites.To prove this, we looked at whether or not SimilarWeb gave estimates for the top 100 sites in the world, according to Ahrefs Rank. SimilarWeb gave estimates for all of them.Back to the data:Because SimilarWeb only gave traffic estimates for roughly ‚Öï of sites, all our findings are based on a sample size of just 24 websites. This is admittedly rather small.You should, therefore, take our findings with a massive pinch of salt.2. Find out how much traffic a website gets from search enginesIt‚Äôs true that there are a few organic traffic estimation tools on the market. But we‚Äôre clearly biased towards our tool (Ahrefs) and convinced that it has the best quality data.Here are the traffic-related estimates we give you:Estimated monthly visits from Google (worldwide);Estimated traffic value (i.e., the equivalent cost of monthly organic traffic for the website or URL if bought via PPC);Estimated number of keywords (in the top 100) that the website ranks for in Google.Let‚Äôs look at the traffic estimates in Ahrefs for ahrefs.com (how meta!), as of July 2018:You can see that ahrefs.com gets an estimated 270,000 monthly visitors from Google.This is a ‚Äúlive‚Äù traffic estimate, meaning that it‚Äôs a ‚Äúrolling average.‚Äù It gets adjusted each time we update the pool of keywords for which the website ranks in our database. Because of this, traffic estimates can vary slightly from day to day. This number includes both desktop and mobile traffic.Do you want to see traffic estimates for a subsection of a website?Just paste any subdomain or subfolder (e.g., ahrefs.com/blog or blog.ahrefs.com) into Site Explorer. Select the ‚ÄúPrefix‚Äù option from the drop-down.For example, if you enter ahrefs.com/blog, you see the total sum of search traffic across all pages within the ‚Äú/blog/‚Äù folder, like so:If you want to look at the traffic to each page within this folder, use the Top Pages report. It will show a list of pages sorted by traffic (from high to low).But this is global traffic. Click the Organic Search tab on the Overview report, and you will see traffic broken down by 170 countries.Sidenote. Just hit ‚ÄúShow more‚Äù to reveal the full list of 170 countries. You‚Äôll also notice that we plot historic organic traffic estimates on a graph. This shows daily organic traffic estimates for as far back as mid-2015. It‚Äôs fully interactive too. Just roll over the graph to see estimated traffic stats for any date over the years.Want to see this graph filtered for a specific country? You can do that.Here it is filtered to show only traffic estimates for the United Kingdom:But wait, there‚Äôs more: go to the Organic keywords report, and we‚Äôll show all the keywords driving traffic to the site, starting with those driving the most traffic.Bottomline: Ahrefs kicks back tons of data for almost any website or URL. But how?Where does the data come from?Ahrefs‚Äô estimates are based on ranking data from our database of 6.1 BILLION keywords.This database is updated monthly, including the search volume estimates (check out a few fun search stats from last month here)Here‚Äôs what we do to calculate traffic estimates in a nutshell:Take all the keywords for which a website ranks;Check monthly search volume, ranking position, and click-through rate for each keyword (across 170 countries);Estimate how much traffic the site gets from each keyword;Sum up these numbers to estimate the total organic traffic a site receives.You can learn more about exactly how we calculate this number here.Is this data accurate?Let‚Äôs test it. Here‚Äôs what we did:Took that same sample of 116 websites from Flippa (all of which showed verified global organic search traffic numbers);Pulled organic traffic numbers from Ahrefs for all 116 websites;Compared them.Here‚Äôs what we found:Ahrefs underestimated organic unique visitors for 74.14% of the websites.Ahrefs underestimated organic unique visitors by 38.08% on average;Ahrefs underestimated organic pageviews for 90.52% of the websites;Ahrefs underestimated organic pageviews by 52.04% on average.To summarise, Ahrefs tends to underestimate organic unique visitors and pageviews, according to our testing. But it doesn‚Äôt always underestimates things; it overestimates organic unique visitors roughly 1/4th of the time, and organic pageviews roughly 1/10th of the time.Sidenote. By the way, these findings are based on a larger sample size than our SimilarWeb data, because Ahrefs showed estimates for all 116 of the sites we tested. (Remember that SimilarWeb only gave estimated for roughly ‚Öï of them?)But why does Ahrefs tend to underestimate traffic anyhow?It‚Äôs because we can only estimate traffic from the 6.1 BILLION keywords we have in our database. Sound like a lot? It is, we have the biggest database of all similar tools on the market.But even a database of 6.1B keywords isn‚Äôt enough to hold every possible search query that one could type into Google. That would be impossible.For example, a lot of people perform super long-tail searches‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ which we don‚Äôt have in our database and, therefore, can‚Äôt estimate the traffic from.This is how all organic traffic estimation tools work, so we‚Äôre not alone here. They all tend to underestimate traffic. The degree to which this happens comes down to the size of their keywords database; the bigger it is, the more accurate their traffic estimations will be.This is why it matters that we (Ahrefs) have the biggest keywords database on the market.It‚Äôs also worth noting that no-one has totally accurate search volume estimations, not even Google. This is another reason that our estimates tend to be underestimations.Which tool is best for comparing multiple sites?Sometimes, it‚Äôs not so much about estimating traffic with insane precision, but rather being able to compare the relative popularity of two or more sites.For example, imagine that you have a list of one hundred outreach prospects, and you want to prioritize your outreach efforts starting with the sites that receive the most traffic.In this case, you want to compare the sites to each other and rank them in order of traffic.So which tool is best for doing this?To learn that, we‚Äôll run a Spearman correlation on our data.Here are the results for SimilarWeb:Actual ‚ÄúUnique visitors‚Äù VS SimilarWeb Total visitsActual ‚ÄúPageviews‚Äù VS SimilarWeb ‚ÄúPageViews‚Äù0.7130.779‚Ä¶ and Ahrefs: Actual ‚ÄúUnique organic visitors‚Äù VS Ahrefs ‚ÄúGlobal‚Äù organic traffic Actual ‚ÄúOrganic Pageviews‚Äù VS Ahrefs ‚ÄúGlobal‚Äù organic traffic0.7670.784Confused?Here‚Äôs what a Spearman correlation shows:Spearman‚Äôs Rank correlation coefficient is a technique which can be used to summarise the strength and direction (negative or positive) of a relationship between two variables. The result will always be between 1 and minus 1. Rank the two data sets.Even more confused? Let me explain (with examples).We‚Äôre looking at the correlation between two sets of data: the ‚Äúreal‚Äù traffic numbers (set #1) and the estimated traffic (set #2). If the numbers positively correlate in any way, the Spearman correlation will be between zero and 1. If they negatively correlate, it will be between zero and -1.So, the closer the correlation is to 1, the more of a positive correlation there is between the two data sets.Let‚Äôs assume we have three websites with the following actual traffic‚Ä¶Site1 - 100Site2 - 5,000Site3 - 40,000‚Ä¶ and Ahrefs reports the following traffic estimates‚Ä¶Site1 - 50Site2 - 2,000Site3 - 10,000‚Ä¶ that would be a perfect positive correlation of 1. (The ‚Äúrank‚Äù of the corresponding numbers in each dataset have a perfect positive correlation with each other)But if Ahrefs estimated the traffic stats as follows‚Ä¶Site1 - 10,000Site2 - 2,000Site3 - 50‚Ä¶ that would be a perfect negative correlation of -1. (The ‚Äúrank‚Äù of the corresponding numbers in each dataset have a perfect negative positive correlation with each other)So basically, the higher the correlation, the better the tool is for comparing two or more sites.Looking at the Spearman correlation data above, you can see that both Ahrefs and SimilarWeb have a strong positive correlation with ‚Äúreal‚Äù traffic. But Ahrefs does trump SimilarWeb, marginally.This means that should you use our Batch Analysis tool to obtain domain-level traffic estimates for a bunch of outreach prospects, then sort by traffic (high to low)‚Ä¶‚Ä¶this is likely to be a pretty good judge of the relative popularity of these sites.So which traffic estimation tool should you use?It‚Äôs important to note that each of these tools do different things.SimilarWeb estimates total traffic, whereas Ahrefs estimates organic (i.e., Google) traffic.One of the unique benefits of SimilarWeb is that you can see where the majority of traffic to a website is coming from (e.g., organic search, social, etc.):You can see, for example, that thewirecutter.com gets roughly 2/3 of its traffic from search engines, according to SimilarWeb.Which brings us to a cool point:If you see that a site gets a lot of traffic from organic search in SimilarWeb, you can use Ahrefs to dig deeper and better understand that traffic.For example, in the case of thewirecutter.com, Ahrefs can show how organic traffic has grown over the past 3+ years‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ or every single one of the 3.1 MILLION keywords it ranks for‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ or the pages responsible for bringing the most organic traffic to the site‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ and a whole lot more!But enough bragging! üòâ Let‚Äôs talk briefly about pricing.SimilarWeb don‚Äôt publish pricing information on their website. But this Quora thread puts their cheapest plan (which gives you access to only 6 months worth of traffic data) at $199/month.That‚Äôs double the cost of our lowest plan. We also have a free version of our toolset, Ahrefs Webmaster Tools, whereas SimilarWeb offers no such thing.But before you make a decision, let‚Äôs take a look at a couple of other ways to find out how much traffic a website gets.Method 2. Look for an ‚Äúadvertise with us‚Äù pageMost bloggers receive so many ‚ÄúI‚Äôm interested in advertising on your site; how much traffic does it get?‚Äù emails that it makes sense to publish this information on a publicly accessible advertising page.Here‚Äôs one such page from geekwire.com:It states their monthly unique visitors, pageviews, and some other useful information (e.g., social stats). It‚Äôs not just the big sites that do this, either; I‚Äôve seen a lot of individual bloggers with similar pages.But how do you find these pages anyhow?The easiest way is with the following Google search:site:website.com advertise with usNine times out of 10, if they have such a page, it will be the first result.Not seeing traffic stats on the advertising page? See if there‚Äôs a link to a ‚Äúmedia pack;‚Äù a lot of sites include their traffic stats here.Still, this tactic doesn‚Äôt always work for three simple reasons:Not all websites have ‚Äúadvertise with us‚Äù pages;Traffic stats aren‚Äôt always published on them;Traffic numbers aren‚Äôt always up-to-dateIf you do find an ‚Äúadvertise with us‚Äù page with traffic stats, always try to check if they‚Äôre up to date.Most websites will list when they were last updated‚Ä¶example from TravelFashionGirl.com‚Ä¶ but some don‚Äôt.For example, the traffic stats shown on the geekwire.com advertising page haven‚Äôt been updated for at least a year.If the website hasn‚Äôt updated their traffic stats recently (or simply fails to give a ‚Äúlast updated‚Äù date), don‚Äôt trust the numbers; they‚Äôre unlikely to be accurate.Method 3. Ask!If you want to know accurate, up-to-date traffic statistics for a website, you‚Äôll need to get in touch with the owner and ask them directly.But most bloggers aren‚Äôt going to give out that information to a complete stranger, right?You‚Äôd be surprised. Many bloggers are perfectly willing to share this data with those with a genuine reason for asking, such as:You‚Äôre interested in buying their website.You want to advertise on their site;Here‚Äôs an example email that I‚Äôve used in the past when trying to find out traffic statistics:Sidenote. We don‚Äôt advise sending emails like this unless you‚Äôre genuinely looking for advertising opportunities. Don‚Äôt waste people‚Äôs time! Like I said, most bloggers will be happy to share up-to-date traffic numbers with genuine advertisers. Many will even screenshot Google Analytics data as proof.While this method is typically the most reliable way to decipher traffic stats, it‚Äôs not 100% foolproof. Here‚Äôs why:Some bloggers/webmasters will fabricate traffic stats in order to sell advertising;Not everyone has Google Analytics installed. Many will rely on less than accurate analytics platforms (e.g., WordPress plugins) for their data;Google Analytics can be easily misinstalled, meaning that data isn‚Äôt always accurate. If reported traffic sounds too high, try checking their website for duplicate GA code. Alternatively, ask them what their bounce rate is; a super-low bounce rate is often a good indicator of duplicate GA code.So even if do reach out to the blogger and get those elusive traffic stats, we would still recommend verifying their legitimacy with third-party tools.Here are a few more tips for estimating website traffic‚Ä¶Estimated traffic stats are a good starting point, but you can tell a lot about the popularity of a website by manually checking a few things, such as:# of comments on their posts (on average);# of YouTube video views;# of social shares;Engagement levels on their fan pages (i.e., Facebook page, Twitter, etc.)If you take a look at the Ahrefs blog, for example, you‚Äôll see that virtually every blog post has a good number of comments.Most readers don‚Äôt bother leaving a comment, no matter how great the content happens to be. So a blog that receives a consistently high number of comments will almost certainly be getting a significant amount of traffic.Sidenote. I‚Äôd also recommend checking the quality of comments when using this tactic; sometimes high comment counts are due to a site being spammed.‚ÄúSocial shares‚Äù can be another indication of high traffic.For example, if we check the Top Content report for ahrefs.com in Site Explorer, we can see that most of the posts on Ahrefs‚Äô blog receive tons of social shares.And finally, there‚Äôs YouTube‚Ä¶All our videos on YouTube have hundreds or thousands of views.If this amount of people are watching our YouTube videos, well, it‚Äôs probably safe to say that a fair few are visiting our site too.Final thoughtsTraffic estimation tools aren‚Äôt perfect. However, they do offer by far the quickest way to estimate traffic to sites you don‚Äôt own.If you need accurate numbers, you‚Äôll have to ask directly; there are no two ways about it.Do you know of any other reliable ways to estimate/find website traffic stats? Let us know.
